summary.suggested_edit: In a recent X post replying to Greg Autry (co-author of Navarro's 'Death by China'), a user stated: 'Oh yes. Free trade benefits the laptop class. Their real wages go up. Working class, not so much. Cheaper consumer goods do not make up for the wage stagnation.' This aligns with the book's critique of free trade policies disproportionately benefiting elites over the working class.
summary.original_text: In Death by China: Confronting the Dragon – A Global Call to Action, co-authored with Greg Autry and published in 2011

summary.suggested_edit: Brian Lilley posted on X: 'I've been saying that waiting Trump out would cost real jobs. The Elbows UP retirees and laptop class said no deal was the…', critiquing delays in trade deals under Trump and their impact on jobs, distinguishing between working class and 'laptop class'.
summary.original_text: For instance, in 2025, Lilley critiqued Canada's trade vulnerabilities amid U.S. tariff threats under President Donald Trump, highlighting Ontario's $75 million ad campaign misusing Ronald Reagan's words as a failed attempt to influence negotiations, which prompted Trump to halt talks. [19] [20]

summary.suggested_edit: On December 7, 2025 (marking 11 years since the trade), X user @MaxMannis recalled: '11 years ago today: The Yankees trade for Didi Gregorius, and a young seventh grade Max Mannis gets in trouble for gasping w…' upon hearing the news in class.
summary.original_text: On December 5, 2014, the Diamondbacks traded Gregorius to the New York Yankees in a three-team deal also involving the Detroit Tigers; Arizona received outfielder Peter O'Brien from New York and pitcher Robbie Ray from Detroit, while the Tigers acquired pitcher Shane Greene from the Yankees.
